title: There was a Red Post a while back.
body:
And in the post (paraphrasing a little) it said that Rioters looked for *quality* of feedback rather than *quantity* of words or threads.

So I decided to be a little more brief than usual about my feedback and condense what I feel I'd like to say into a few sentences. I'm not going to couch my terms nicely or give specifics, because that's been done before.
I believe that currently, Riot's designers:

* Have replaced the strategic engagements of older League with a battle of reflex and reaction time, weakening the more cerebral portions of League in exchange for flashier play potential, which threatens to damage League's core element of gameplay, which still is *strategy*, not *speed*,

* Have created mobility champions that excel at counterplay simply by virtue of being mobile instead of having specific counterplay abilities, and therefore thrive in an environment where most skills are now skillshots and where pure tanks, with their more reliable CC, are weak,

* Have largely reduced point-and-click CC, the largest counter to mobility, further buffing mobility champions,

* Produce champions whose kits give them far too many options on what they do and how they do it, at great expense to champions with more clearly defined weaknesses, because generalist champions are very easily able to use their large number of abilities to find and capitalize on the weaknesses of other champions while still remaining extremely safe,

* Produce champions that do not have a true weakness, or have a weakness that is largely irrelevant, who proceed to dominate the meta until they have to be nerfed and then become simply mediocre at everything and therefore useless,

* Often produce uninspired solutions to problematic portions of a champion's kit that could easily be addressed with a more creative solution rather than a flat nerf or buff,

* Often buff champions after release, before the playerbase has fully adapted to that champion and learned how to play them, making them ludicrously strong when the playerbase adapts,

* Have not fixed some very obviously overtuned champions at the expense of every other champion.

* Have failed to clearly and reasonably address the *absolutely* devastated lore,

* Often stonewall community feedback, leading to considerable frustration when *nothing happens* despite loud, continued, unanimous community feedback asking for a change.

Riot, I don't need to sing your praises about what you've done right. I believe that there are a *lot* of things you have done and presumably will continue to do right, and I appreciate the thought you put into your work. 

For what it's worth? You're my favorite game company, and if I didn't think you were good, I wouldn't tell you what I thought, because I wouldn't care at all. Your power has always been listening to your playerbase and acting for feedback. I ask you to continue doing that, despite that not being strictly necessary, because I believe it is integral to the community you have built. I would hate to see Riot fall into the trap of 'we've got 'em, now we can ignore them' and then throw us under the bus. So far, that's been far from the case, but recent changes have worried me.

Thank you for your time.

EDIT: And thank you for all the upvotes. Wow. Thanks.

I will forever upvote this post. This is what feedback should look like- you stated your opinion in a concise and calm way and managed not to make it a huge text wall. I applaud you on both your manners and the way you went about this.

I agree with your opinion on the rise of mobility- recently, immobile champions have become slightly problematic. However, it feels to me like Riot is in some sort of testing-the-waters stage right now. I feel this because the idea of champion diversity and some recent champion changes and releases recently is **very hard to draw parallels between.** Also, from what I hear about Riot's past (Joined mid s4, lacking in history), they have never been a company to ignore players. I feel like change will come soon, possibly with the release of Bard?

 '#mandrakeward

From what I've seen and heard, Riot is always wanting to raise the bar and bring new and exciting feats to the rift in order to keep things fresh and continue to attract new players.
There are some that seem to dislike this, wanting the game to remain as it had back in S2.
While I can understand the sentiment, this would have caused League to become stale long ago.
As Riot continues to expand in the realm of ideas to implement to the rift, the player base has to expand on what it sees as balanced or else you leave no room for anything new or exciting.  You run into the point where after a certain point, you're going to simply have cookie cutter champs with nothing really making them unique or exciting.

> [{quoted}](name=Kuroi86,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=tudnEmGv,comment-id=00000001,timestamp=2015-02-21T08:29:13.416+0000)

What do you mean by this?

I don't understand it either.

Balanced isn't about particular abilities or strengths, it's about a champion having strengths and weaknesses, reasons to pick them over other champions, but also reasons not to.

The idea of balance does not change no matter how many new abilities are added.

> [{quoted}](name=Nameless Voice,realm=EUW,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=tudnEmGv,comment-id=0000000100000000,timestamp=2015-02-21T15:20:22.050+0000)
>
> I don't understand it either.
> 
> Balanced isn't about particular abilities or strengths, it's about a champion having strengths and weaknesses, reasons to pick them over other champions, but also reasons not to.
> 
> The idea of balance does not change no matter how many new abilities are added.

Exactly.

Nasus is balanced. Sometimes (weak enemy top lane, farm oriented team comp, enemy has protect-the-kog team comp) he is an awesome pick. Sometimes (strong enemy top lane, facing mobility, enemy has multiple strongly scaling champions) he is a weak pick.

This is how Dota is balanced as well. Almost everyone is the best pick ever in certain circumstances and completely useless in certain other circumstances.

The glut of champions that are good at everything (starting at around champion 100 - Jayce; there was a time when bruisers had all the tools as an answer to ranged dominance but the overload didn't creep into other roles, now it does) has made champion select irrelevant except as a place to ban/secure the champions with the highest numbers, because there is no longer a point in picking strategically.

This actually makes balance issues *worse*. When there is no reason to pick one champion over another unless its stats are better, the champion that is even slightly better at its role becomes overwhelmingly strong because there is no weakness for other champions to exploit. This is why balance is so bad in S5. Most champions are not actually shit, but they have no answer to a champion that is just 5% better across the board.

> [{quoted}](name=Retillin,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=tudnEmGv,comment-id=000000010000,timestamp=2015-02-21T15:11:48.834+0000)
>
> What do you mean by this?

He means people need to stop equating counterplay with "can I dodge it". People who come out of the woodwork to cry that old Veigar had no counterplay *just* because you couldn't dodge his stun should be drawn and quartered.

Veigar's main counterplay comes from the fact that he's a very weak laner with heavy mana issues and no real escape, and playing around the cooldown of his stun.

The problem with Veigar is really that a huge amount of his power budget goes into that stun field, meaning that he has to be excessively weak in other areas to compensate (which is why he generally isn't considered viable.)

Personally, I'd rather see him lose some power there and gain more power in other areas.  However, the problem remains that they are rebalancing Veigar in terms of other "normal" champions, which means that he will now be even more useless against the favoured high-mobility top picks.

I don't think that's problem with the idea behind the Veigar rework, though.  The changes are good ideas and open him up for more power in other areas, but they are just meaningless while so many other champions with super-overloaded kits still exist.

Just wanted to jump in here say a few things, but first to talk about the post itself: great job! The feedback is constructive and well written. I don't personally agree with everything being reflective of the state of how things are now, but rather the state of things year(s) ago. That said. that's just my opinion -- I don't represent the opinions of the team that this feedback is for. I know they're reading it though.

I digress.

I found the end state of this discussion interesting, and would like to point out a few things. 

1. Because the post itself was constructive, the rest of the conversation trended the same way. Yes people disagreed with some of the feedback points, but it really didn't become uncivil at any point. Super happy about that!

2. Look at how many votes it received, and is continuing to receiving over 24 hours later. The quality of the post, in addition to others agreement of the feedback caused many Boards users to vote, and that has subsequently put it in the most visible place of the Boards for over a day. This is a testament, and should be used as an example for anyone wanting to get more visibility on their content. I [posted a blurb about why voting is important](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/miscellaneous/tjRUtkyh-voting-on-boards-content) last month, feel free to check that out for more information about that.

Thanks for the post, I hope the development team jumps in here at some point to give you their 2 cents.

As do we.

I'm glad someone in RIOT at least read this. But still, I feel like rioters intentionally ignore posts or just don't usually read them. I can list a few posts that are civil, constructed and well-reasoned enough for rioters to post and say something, and yet no one of them have any answer.

And thank *you* for posting.

Even if you personally disagree it is *immensely* vindicating to see a Rioter respond to my post. It means a lot to see that you are actually looking at and reading what we say.

(Also, you missed out on a *golden* Vel'koz joke opportunity. #ritopls)

>Thanks for the post, I hope the development team jumps in here at some point to give you their 2 cents.

If they don't is a self proving point. 

>* Often stonewall community feedback, leading to considerable frustration when nothing happens despite loud, continued, unanimous community feedback asking for a change.

It's not even about making the change. It's about appearing to straight up ignoring feedback, whether or not the feedback is something Riot follows is their choice, but not even a "We see this, but no." or "Seems legit." makes it look pretty bad when the ignored feedback points at a potential problem that then unfolds as predicted.

> I don't personally agree with everything being reflective of the state of how things are now, but rather the state of things year(s) ago.

Except over the span of year(s), nothing communication wise has changed outside of the boards replacing ye olde GD. In fact, it seems Rioter communication has taken a general downtrend from years of old, especially on subjects like this.

>That said. that's just my opinion -- I don't represent the opinions of the team that this feedback is for.

I know you aren't really part of the team this thread is pointed at, but the results should be of interest to the Boards team. Their platform hasn't been successful at increasing or fixing the communication issues. I don't even think that the format matters so much as nothing is addressing the elephant in the room. Communication on this scale takes dedication. And I get that developers should be dedicated to their job, which isn't necessarily communication. So how will this dedication crisis be resolved?

You've already shot down CM's, so I will suggest something that I know your gut will instinctively shoot down. Bring back the Riot Ambassadors:

>ARE YOU INSAYAN PRYOTRA!?!?!?! NEVAR AGAIN!!!!

Okay, yeah, the old version of the ambassadors flopped, but I feel the idea behind them was spot on. They were not designed to replace Rioters on the forums. They were designed to be in betweens, effectively bridges between the community and the various parts of Riot. However, they were implemented in the worst possible way, more like walls between the community and Riot, ultimately leading to their failure. With proper implementation, that initial idea could very well be highly sucessful.

So, with that in mind, what should the new "Ambassadors" do differently?

* **No More Copy Pasta** - I think we can all agree that Copy pasta responses generally don't play well with large scale communications. Make them more Human, and allow them to type their own sentences.

* **More "Fowarded to X department"** - This way we can know when and who got the info sent to them.

* **Personalized names** - Allow them to have their own personalities. Don't make them just sign for the same account. That's just dumb.

* **New color for posts** - Kinda like the wrenchmen get that special orange name, allow them to get their own color to distinguish them from players, but also not forcing them up on the Red Tracker for simple "forwarded" messages.

* **Don't make them Answer for riot** - Instead, give some general FAQ's for some of the departments that are easy to find, so that if it is a question that has been answered 100 times before, the answer can be easily found. If they are easily found, the community can link them for the player and point out where the answer is, so that nobody at Riot needs to waste time answering "Do Unique Passives Stack?" or other obvious questions.

In the end, I feel that the Ambassador's could have worked as imagined. As implemented, they were more like moderators that tried to keep the forums clean of controversial topics. Keeping true to the idea should have better results in further implementations. And no, you don't have to keep the name "Ambassadors" if you don't want to. =P

> [{quoted}](name=Tamat,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=tudnEmGv,comment-id=002e,timestamp=2015-02-22T12:43:28.198+0000)
> Thanks for the post, I hope the development team jumps in here at some point to give you their 2 cents.

So do I, Tamat.

As a person who has been playing LoL a long time I remember when a dash was a significant thing. Gragas was the first champ released when I started, and a dash, a directional dash? That was an immense power house. The fact that he had 2 defensive abilities was compensation for the mobility given. W was a nearly passive buff that gave protections and AD damage and passive was a nice regen ability. I play a lot of the older champions because well, I like them, Singed, Rammus, Old and new sion, these are my jam and I feel like I cant play the game how I want to anymore. I HAVE to pick Vi, J4 or Lee to be a good jungler, or I HAVE to learn gnar for top, or nid/LB or zed for mid. It forces the game into such a narrow view that so many champions feel obsolete, barely playable or even on whole separate levels compared to the new champions released. How is a Singed EVER supposed to catch a Kalista? How is a Rammus EVER going to catch a Nidalee? It wont happen unless a major misplay on the enemy is made. Champions have come from 'oh, this guy does X, but he's not good at Z' to 'This guy is good at X, Y, Z, Q, R, 7 and 12, but if you ban him, you can avoid him.'

This is one of the big things that i don't think riot ever considered when they were designing champions. They talk about counter-play all the time, but more often than not when it comes to champions with high mobility, they have to make a major mistake to actually be counter-played by the champions who have significantly less in their kits.

Like consider something like {{champion:64}}  vs {{champion:48}}, the only way a trundle has any chance of killing lee is if lee mistakenly engages on trundle while not being able to win the fight outright. Wastes his W on positioning, and fails to use his R correctly. For trundle to win against lee sin, he was to hope lee sin does all of those things, while he is actually able to beat him in a strait fight.

I just played a Trundle jungle against a Nidalee, a BAD Nidalee, and she still ended up 2 levels ahead of me due to her insane counterjungling early on. There was a time where she tosses a trap over the wall on golems I am fighting, hits a spear on the golem, pounces over, executes them with too much burst to fight against, then sees me, I club her and pin her to the wall with my pillar and attack her, she just hops right over like its no big deal. How is that counterplay? I should have had her in the bad easy, but mobility wins again for reasons unknown. LCS BIG PLAYZ.

> [{quoted}](name=Thefriendlyorc,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=tudnEmGv,comment-id=000300010000,timestamp=2015-02-21T21:24:13.317+0000)

There was a time where she tosses a trap over the wall on golems I am fighting, hits a spear on the golem, pounces over, executes them with too much burst to fight against, then sees me, I club her and pin her to the wall with my pillar and attack her, she just hops right over like its no big deal. How is that counterplay? I should have had her in the bad easy, but mobility wins again for reasons unknown. LCS BIG PLAYZ.

Only some champions get to counterplay and have only advantages. Others only get to be counterplayed and have only disadvantages. It's up to you to figure out who Riot's favorites are.
To be fair, unless Nid jumps over a wall or two, she's not getting away from ~~Sonic~~ Rammus.

sadly riot is still going to ignore you. The balance team does not even listen to itself.

> [{quoted}](name=Abyssal Plunge,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=tudnEmGv,comment-id=,timestamp=2015-02-21T04:18:48.391+0000)
>
> And in the post (paraphrasing a little) it said that Rioters looked for *quality* of feedback rather than *quantity* of words or threads.

Heyas! So I want to start off by saying that your feedback is definitely quality. It is still a bit much to digest, and doesn't have a great jumping off point, especially if a particular Rioter doesn't have the time, fortitude, or expertise to dig into all of your questions.  I am sadly a bit short on time, but I'll check back in here for the next hour and then towards the end of day tomorrow.  Thank you for the collection of feedback. 

> I believe that currently, Riot's designers:
> 
> * Have replaced the strategic engagements of older League with a battle of reflex and reaction time, weakening the more cerebral portions of League in exchange for flashier play potential, which threatens to damage League's core element of gameplay, which still is *strategy*, not *speed*,

This is the most interesting topic to me so forgive me if I delve in a bit.  What strategic engagements of yesteryear are you yearning for?  When I've been in this conversation internally it boils down to, "Fiddlesticks could turn the game around with a good ultimate and there were global teams," and now that doesn't necessarily ring as true. Is that because the game has fundamentally changed? Certainly, Fiddle's fear doesn't last as long and there are more available countermeasures... but to me it's primarily a function of players getting faster, and partly due to them being more mobile. Interrupting an ultimate is a lot more feasible now, in large part because of people's quick reactions and in some part because people have got better at the strategy, and know how to avoid the big surprise parties.  

I feel like other strategic elements of the game have become more and more prevalent in League.  Trinkets helped more people buy into the vision game, and a year later, there's still an upwards trend in number of wards placed and destroyed.  

S2015 brought about more focus on objectives.  Dragon became 'the thing'.  Much of competitive play has balanced out in terms of people's talent. You can't count on people winning lane consistently, you have to out-rotate and out-vision.  

I guess this loops back around to: what are the strategic elements that are being underplayed?  What could we bring back into the fold?

> (paraphrasing a ton): champs are too generally strong, without any actual weakness, too much mobility creates free counterplay, point & click CC is down

I don't have a lot to add to these points.  GC talked a bit about mobility over here: http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/2TavB1Ax-dear-riot-can-we-get-a-straight-no-nonsense-description-of-what-your-vision-for-this-game-is?comment=0016 earlier today.  I can say you're right, we're reducing targeted CC.  The goal obviously isn't to make mobile people stronger, but that is a side effect and we should be cognizant of that.  

I know it's also a goal of the champion team to have actual weaknesses on their champions. To the extent that isn't the case, your feedback and call-outs are warranted.  

> * Often produce uninspired solutions to problematic portions of a champion's kit that could easily be addressed with a more creative solution rather than a flat nerf or buff,

The more creative a solution, generally  the more divisive it will be and the harder to finalize.  I am often a proponent of less creative changes (straight tuning), when champs are simply out of line but perhaps that's why that's not my job. ;)  

> * Often buff champions after release, before the playerbase has fully adapted to that champion and learned how to play them, making them ludicrously strong when the playerbase adapts,

Guilty as charged.  It is frequently very difficult to avoid.  A designer has spent around a year on a champion.  It's released, they suddenly see tons on tons of players using the champion. They spot some quality of life fixes they can make. They are going to make them, because they just make the champion holistically better. Then it's a question of, "should we 'compensation' nerf this champion along with these QoL changes?" and since the community thinks the champion is underwhelming, the answer is frequently no.  And then there are other times we miscalculate.

> * Have not fixed some very obviously overtuned champions at the expense of every other champion.

Are we talking the Lee Sin variety or some separate beast?  Generally agreed that some champions stick around too long.  

> * Have failed to clearly and reasonably address the *absolutely* devastated lore,

This is way out of my wheelhouse, sorry. :( 

> * Often stonewall community feedback, leading to considerable frustration when *nothing happens* despite loud, continued, unanimous community feedback asking for a change.

This is certainly never our intent.  Not all feedback will be acted on, but on the flipside: our aim is to make the game better for players.  We only know that the game is better/worse based on your feedback. I do say 'your' in a very general sense, though.  There have been instances when these forums have been much more negative about a change than the general populace (as taken from surveys in the game).   I think the more constructive posts like yours we have and the more dialogue we create, the better off the game will be.  

> For what it's worth? You're my favorite game company, and if I didn't think you were good, I wouldn't tell you what I thought, because I wouldn't care at all. 

Thank you for caring!  We care, too.  A lot!

Pretty tired, But let me try to address what I can in my half awake stupor...

>This is certainly never our intent. Not all feedback will be acted on, but on the flipside: our aim is to make the game better for players. We only know that the game is better/worse based on your feedback. I do say 'your' in a very general sense, though. There have been instances when these forums have been much more negative about a change than the general populace (as taken from surveys in the game). I think the more constructive posts like yours we have and the more dialogue we create, the better off the game will be.

I don't think that was the point. I never expect Riot to act on everything that gets posted on the boards. That said, There are alot of quality pieces that go un-commented on, and some of it feedback that turns out to be spot on, and yet we rarely see anything from that department. Dialogue is a 2 way street, and even saying "yeah.... NO." is better than not even posting. Ok, maybe not necessarily better, but knowing that a relevant Rioter has seen it helps set alot of people at ease. And currently, there just isn't any way to know if anyone that is relevant has seen it unless they post.

>This is way out of my wheelhouse, sorry. :(

Does this wheel house still exist in Riot? The only department quieter than them is the legal department. Seriously, even your pricing guys talk more than them, and they only do when pagan rituals are invoked. Another issue that ties in to the above, I guess, and I know it isn't your wheel house. But it's SUPER frustrating not being able to talk about patching things up between the community and them *because they never have a discussion with us*.

>Are we talking the Lee Sin variety or some separate beast? Generally agreed that some champions stick around too long.

I'm curious on the definition of "Lee Sin variety". Does he live in his own league, or is there a Lee and Co. that you are referring to?

Btw, there are others that are pretty painfully obviously out of line. Kat maintaining both an incredible play rate *and* high winrate? Constant complaining at all levels of play about Kalista? *Notice the high mobility trend?*

>The more creative a solution, generally the more divisive it will be and the harder to finalize. I am often a proponent of less creative changes (straight tuning), when champs are simply out of line but perhaps that's why that's not my job. ;)

As a counterpoint, sometimes the more "creative" fixes aren't straight buffs/nerfs but still very easy to implement and test. As an example, lets use Kallista's over the top mobility. The easy solution would be to just gut her hop range so that people have a way to catch up. A creative fix would be to apply slows to the hops, so that she hops "slower" or just travels less distance during the hop. Probably a bad example because I'm tired as hell, but I hope you see the point.

While I agree with a lot of your points on mobility and how it has made some forms of engagement and fighting obsolete there is something that I think a lot of people forget, so I am going to play devils advocate here:

Perhaps those players are only in that position because they are aware their mobility will save them. Its the same idea as someone who has flash on CD playing more cautiously than when they have flash up. A common issue in low-mid tier play are people acting as if flash and jumps don't exist and believing they got cheated out of a kill when the enemy player uses that ability to avoid a CC or ability. There are some champs who definitely do abuse their mobility to avoid situations that should otherwise get them killed (lee sin/nidalee) but that is merely because they know that safety net is there which lets them throw caution to the wind.

The bigger issue in this situation (excluding the nid/lee/kassadin) is that less mobile champs tend to have their weakness defined by this ability the mobile champ is probably dodging. So if you are Anivia  who uses Q or W you are extremely vulnerable while the enemy mobile champ can generally miss abilities and escape despite their mistake.. If you are an Ashe and the Lucian dodges your ult you cant win that fight. Meanwhile if you are the Ashe and dodge Lucians Q W or R he can choose whether he wants to fight. Basically the more mobile champ always dictates when a fight is going to happen, and can choose a situation that is more favorable to them. This situation can be countered by having a team built around your weakness, but in a Solo Q situation players frequently wont want to choose a Janna or Thresh just because you chose Anivia or Ashe.

The solution I see to this is actually not as much in champ balance as it is in item design. Ashe will never be as good as Graves or Lucian because with the same items Graves and Lucian offer burst and mobility with only a slight drop in damage over time. If item diversity did more to separate damage potential then you would see a purpose for less mobile champs if they offered something more than novelty. If Ahri and Brand are rushing the same items with similar damage, but Ahri lets me have all that safety then why would I choose Brand. To bring out this item diversity, I think stats need to be stripped from a lot of higher tier items so that the order you rush an item has more of an impact on the early and mid games. Maybe if Morello's only gave mana and CDR but less AP Ahri would go for a more AP focused item. Then in the mid game Brand could be useful by using more spells with CDR and not running oom while Ahri would hit harder but be able to use her spells less.

> Maybe if Morello's only gave mana and CDR but less AP Ahri would go for a more AP focused item. Then in the mid game Brand could be useful by using more spells with CDR and not running oom while Ahri would hit harder but be able to use her spells less.

Sorry, It really bugs me that morello's became THE mana regen item. Shouldn't that have been athenes?

>Perhaps those players are only in that position because they are aware their mobility will save them.

Which is the exact problem of losing the cerebral value in the game. Yes, you could argue it's more cerebral to factor it in, but Honestly that isn't how pro's are looking at it. They don't play Anivia because the Wall is effectively not good due to all the mobility, and therefore have effectively 3 spells while still being immobile. They don't use J4 for the terrain and setup potential of his cataclysm, because that setup potential hardly exists anymore.

This over abundance of mobility needs to end if these abilities are going to find value again. A good start would be removing flash, and compensating immobile champs that relied on it with either range or something else. That said, for the Hyper-mobile, they are going to need to be equalized.

>The bigger issue in this situation (excluding the nid/lee/kassadin) is that less mobile champs tend to have their weakness defined by this ability the mobile champ is probably dodging.

Actually I don't think there weaknesses defined by it, but rather their strengths are being negated. For example, take ashe vs kallista. Ashe really just effectively loses her slow, which is her "big strength" that defines her, and her stun becomes infinitely harder to land, which is her "great equalizer". Meanwhile, assuming the support is next to Kallista, Kallista still has an easy time landing her entire kit because Ashe doesn't have the mobility to dodge, especially with Kallista's press button slow.

I don't think this is a solution, and Riot agrees. And if they did start making items with some form of "anti-mobility clause" you will find that the item would have to give pretty terrible stats for mobile champs to not pick it up, and even then if you did then even the immobile would likely not want it either.
